deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 0% of the units vaccinated.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 0% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 0 units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 25% of the units vaccinated.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 25% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 units should start vaccine immune. Since this is a deterministic test, the vaccinated units will be spread evenly through the population instead of being chosen randomly.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 50% of the units vaccinated.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 50% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 4 units should start vaccine immune. Since this is a deterministic test, the vaccinated units will be spread evenly through the population instead of being chosen randomly.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 75% of the units vaccinated.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 75% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 6 units should start vaccine immune. Since this is a deterministic test, the vaccinated units will be spread evenly through the population instead of being chosen randomly.

deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 100% of the units vaccinated.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 100% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 8 units should start vaccine immune.

stochastic-variable-test.description: Test a scenario with 75% of the units vaccinated.
stochastic-variable-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
stochastic-variable-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 75% of units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - There should always be 6 units vaccine immune on the first simulation day. Which 6 units may differ, but there should always be 6. This test makes sure that a particular herd isn’t chosen twice (or more) for vaccination.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 50% vaccinated in one, 0% in other, pattern 1
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types and different proportions of units vaccinated in each.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 50% of units of type “A” and 0% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “A” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 50% vaccinated in one, 0% in other, pattern 2
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types and different proportions of units vaccinated in each.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 50% of units of type “A” and 0% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “A” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 0% vaccinated in one, 50% in other, pattern 1
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types and different proportions of units vaccinated in each.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 0% of units of type “A” and 50% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “B” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 0% vaccinated in one, 50% in other, pattern 2
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types and different proportions of units vaccinated in each.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 0% of units of type “A” and 50% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “B” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 50% vaccinated in one, 50% in other, pattern 1
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 50% of units of type “A” and 50% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “A” units and 2 of the “B” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.short-name: 2 production types, 50% vaccinated in one, 50% in other, pattern 2
deterministic-test.description: Test a scenario with 2 production types.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
No units are initially infected.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 50% of units of type “A” and 50% of units of type “B”. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days.
What should happen: - 2 of the “A” units and 2 of the “B” units should start vaccine immune.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests the time between vaccinations. In this scenario, there is 1 day between vaccinations (i.e., units are vaccinated every day).
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
In both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 100% of cattle units, but not in pig units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days. The time between vaccinations is 1 day, which means that prophylactic vaccination is done every day.
What should happen: - Unit 1, the cattle unit, starts the simulation infected. It will progress through 1 day latent, 2 days clinical, and on to naturally immune. - Unit 0, the pig unit, will start vaccine immune. The parameter for the time between vaccinations is 1, which means that vaccination happened the day before the simulation begins. So unit 0 will have all 3 days of vaccine immunity.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests the time between vaccinations. In this scenario, there are 3 days between vaccinations.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
In both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 100% of cattle units, but not in pig units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days. The time between vaccinations is 3 days.
What should happen: - Unit 1, the cattle unit, starts the simulation infected. It will progress through 1 day latent, 2 days clinical, and on to naturally immune. - Unit 0, the pig unit, was vaccinated before the simulation begins. The vaccination may have happened between 1 and 3 days before the simulation begins. With fixed “random” numbers of 0.5, we will choose 2 days before the simulation begins. So unit 0 will have 2 days of vaccine immunity remaining.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests the time between vaccinations. In this scenario, there are 5 days between vaccinations.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
In both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 100% of cattle units, but not in pig units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days. The time between vaccinations is 5 days.
What should happen: - Unit 1, the cattle unit, starts the simulation infected. It will progress through 1 day latent, 2 days clinical, and on to naturally immune. - Unit 0, the pig unit, was vaccinated before the simulation begins. The vaccination may have happened between 1 and 5 days before the simulation begins. With fixed “random” numbers of 0.5, we will choose 3 days before the simulation begins. So unit 0 will have 1 day of vaccine immunity remaining.

deterministic-test.description: This is one of 4 scenarios that tests the time between vaccinations. In this scenario, there are 7 days between vaccinations.
deterministic-test.author: Neil Harvey <neilharvey@gmail.com>
deterministic-test.parameter-description:
In both production types, the latent period lasts 1 day, the infectious clinical period lasts 2 days, and immunity lasts 3 days.
Prophylactic vaccination is done in 100% of cattle units, but not in pig units. The vaccine produces immunity immediately, and the immunity lasts 3 days. The time between vaccinations is 7 days.
What should happen: - Unit 1, the cattle unit, starts the simulation infected. It will progress through 1 day latent, 2 days clinical, and on to naturally immune. - Unit 0, the pig unit, was vaccinated before the simulation begins. The vaccination may have happened between 1 and 7 days before the simulation begins. With fixed “random” numbers of 0.5, we will choose 4 days before the simulation begins. So unit 0 will have gone through its 3 days of immunity already and will be back to susceptible.
